command we are presenting the remarkÂ­
able spectacle of Increasing the public
debt by borrowing money to meet the
ordinary outlaya Incident upon even the
economical and prudent administration
of the government
THE GOOD OLD TIMES.
An examination of the subjects disÂ­
closes this fact In every detail and leads
Inevitably to the conclusion that the
condition of the revenue which allows It
Is unjustifiable and should be corrected.
We find by the report of the secretary of
the treasury that the revenues of the
fiscal year ending June 30, 1892, from all

itures for all purposes were $415,953_,806.56
leaving an excess of receipts over expenÂ­

nual Interest charge decreased $11,684,Â­
--576.60. The receipts of the government
from all sources during the fiscal year
ending June 30, 1893, amounted to $416,Â­
--716,561.94, and its expenditures to $469,Â­
--874,887.66, showing an excess of receipts
over expenditures of $254,167.29.
WriEN TROUBLE BEGAN.
Since that time the receipts of no fiscal
year, and with but few exceptions, of no
month of any fiscal year have exceeded
the expenditures. The receipts of thr
government from all sources during the
fiscal year ending June 30, 1894, were
$872,892,488.29, and Its expenditures $442,Â­

$69,983,230.58. Notwithstanding there
waa a decreaae of $16,769,128.78 In the orÂ­
dinary expenses of the government as
compared with the previous fiscal year,
lta income was still not sufficient to proÂ­
vide for Its dally necessities, and the
gold reserve Jn the treasury for the reÂ­
demption of greenbacks was drawn upon
to meet them.

isting conditions. Ample revenues must

lss, was transmitted to Congress in a special

recommendation of the board that the GovÂ­
ernment should encourage the production of
private steel works of the required material
for heavy cannon, and that two Government
factories, one for tiie Army and one for the
Kavy, should be established for the fabricaÂ­

quently reconvened to then determine more

It has received Information which indicates
that there are responsible steel manufacturÂ­
ers in this country, who, although not proÂ­

THE NAVY. .
The report of the Secretary of the Navy exÂ­
hibits the progress which has been made on
the new steel cruisers authorized by the acts
of August 5th, 1882, and March 3d, lo8i. Of the
four vessels under contract one, the Chicago,
of 4,500 tons, is more than half finished ; the
Atlanta, 3,000 tons, has been successfully
launched, and her machinery is now fitting;
the Boston, also of 3,000 tons, is ready for
launching, and the Dolphin, a dispatch
steamer of 1,500 tons Is ready for delivery.
Certain adverse criticisms upon the designs
of these cruisers are discussed by the SecÂ­
retary, who insists that the correctness
of the conclusions " reached by the
Advisory Board and by the DeÂ­
partment has been demonstrated by
recent developments - in ship-building
abroad. The machinery of the doubleÂ­
turreted monitors, Puritan, Terror and
Amphitrite, contracted for under the
act of March 3d, 1883, is in process
of construction. No work has been done
during the past year on their armor, for lack
of the necessary appropriations. A fourth
monitor, the Monadnock. still remains unÂ­
finished at the navy yard in California. It is
recommended that early steps be taken to
complete these vessels, and to provide also
an armament for the monitor Miantonomah.
The recommendations of the Naval Advisory
Board, approved by the department, comÂ­
prise the construction of one steel cruiser of
4,500 tons, one cruiser of 3,000 tons, two heavÂ­
ily armed gunboats, one light cruising gunÂ­
boat, one dispatch vessel armed with HotchÂ­
kiss cannon, one armored ram and three torÂ­
pedo boats. The general designs, all of
which are calculated to meet the existing
wants of the service, are now well advanced
and the construction of the vessols can be
undertaken as soon as you shall grant the
necessary authority. , .. .
THE JEANNETTE VICTIMS.
The act of Congress approved August 7,
1382, authorized the removal to the United
States of the bodies ofUeutenant-Com-mander
George W. DeLong and his comÂ­
panions of the Jeannette expedition.' This
removal has been successfully accomÂ­
plished by Lieutenants Harberand Schuetze.
The remains were taken from their grave
in the Lena Delta in March, 1883, and were reÂ­
tained at Yakutsk until the following winter,
the season being too lar advanced to admit
of their immediate transportation. They arÂ­
rived at New York February 20, 1884, where
they were received with situabie honors.
THE OREELY RELIEF EXPEDITION.
In pursuance of the Joint resolution of
Congress, approved February 13,1884, a naval
exDedition was fitted out tor the relief of 1
Lieutenant A. W.Greely, United States Army,
and of the party who had been engaged unÂ­
der his command in scientific observations
at Lady Franklin Bay. The fleet consisted of
the steam sealer Thetis, purchased la EngÂ­
land; the Bear, purchased at St. Johns, NewÂ­
foundland, and the Alert, which was generÂ­
ously provided by the British Government.
Preparations for the expedition were
promptly made by the Secretary of the Navy,
with the active co-operation of the Secretary
of War. Commander George W. Coffin was
placed In command of the Alert, and LieuÂ­
tenant W. H. Emery In command of the Bear.
The Thetis was intrusted to Commander
Wenfield S. Copley, to whom also was asÂ­
Signed the superintendence ot the entire
expedition. Immediately upon Its arÂ­
rival at Upernavik the fleet began the
dangerous navigation - of Melville Bay,
and, in spite of every obstable, reached LitÂ­
tleton Island on June 22d, a fortnight earlier
than any vessel had before attained that
point. On the same day it crossed over to
Cape Sabine, where Lieutenant Greely and
the other survisors of his party were discovÂ­
ered. After taking on board the living and
the bodies of the dead, the relief ships sailed
for St. Johns, where they arrived on July
17th. They were appropriately received at
Portsmouth, N. IL, on August 1st, and at New
Y'ork on August 8th. One of the bodies was
landed at the former place, - The others were
put on shore at - Governor's Island,- and,
with the exception of one which was InÂ­
terred ha the National Cemetery, were forÂ­
warded thence to the destination indicated
by friends. The . organization and conduct
oi this relief expedition reflects great credit
upon aUwho contributed to ite saoce . - .

SMALL ANNOYANCES.
OR. TALMAGE SAYS THEY ARE INÂ­
FLLCTED FOR A PURPOSE.
We Should Strive to Overcome the
Troubles of Life-With the Help of
God's Grace Petty Grievances BeÂ­
come Blessing..

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8.-This sermon
by Dr. Talmage deals with a subject
which appeals to all classes and condiÂ­
tions of men. His text is Deuteronomy
vii, 20, "The Lord thy God will-send
the hornet."
It seems as if the insectile world
were determined to extirpate the huÂ­
man race. It bombards the grainfields
and the orchards and the vineyards.
The Colorado beetle, the Nebraska
grasshopper, the New Jersey locust,
the universal potato beetle, seem to
carry on the work which was begun
ages ago when the insects buzzed out
of Noah's ark as the door was opened.
In my text the hornet flies out on its
mission. It is a species of wasp, swift
in its motion and violent in its sting..
Its touch is torture to man or beast.
We have all seen the cattle run bellowÂ­
ing under the cut of its lancet. In boyÂ­
hood;.}'e used to stand cautiously lookÂ­
` ifi;~g.attlm globular nest hung from the
tree branch, and while we were lookÂ­
ing at the wonderful covering we were
struck with something that sent us
shrieking away. The hornet goes in
swarms. It has captains over hunÂ­
dreds, and 20 of them alighting on one
man will produce certain death.
The Persians attemhpted to conquer a
Christian city, but the elephants and
the beasts on which the Persians rode
were assaulted by the hornet, so that
the whole army was broken up and the
besieged city was rescued. This burnÂ­
ing and noxious insect stung out the
Hittites and the Canaanites from their
country. What gleaming sword and
chariot of war could not accomplish
was done by the puncture of an insect.
"The Lord sent the hornet."
My friends, when we are assaulted by
great behemoths of trouble we become
chivalric, and we assault them. We
get on the high mottled steed of our
courage, and we make a cavalry charge
at them, and if God be with us we
come out stronger and better than
when we went it. But alas for these
insectile annoyances of life, these foes
too small to shoot, these things withÂ­
out any avoirdupois weight, the gnats
and the midges and the flies and the
wasps and the hornets! In other
wards, It is the small, stinging annoyÂ­
ances of our life which drive us out
and use us up. In the best conditioned
life for some grand and glorious purÂ­
pose God has sent the hornet.
IIumanity Overworked.
I remark, in the first place, that these
small, stinging annoyances may come
in the shape of a nervous organization.
People who are prostrated under tyÂ­
phoid fevers or with broken bones get
plenty of sympathy, but who pities
anybody that is nervous? The doctors
say and the family say and everybody
says, "Oh, she's only a little nervous;
that's all!" The sound of a heavy foot,
the harsh clearing of a throat, a disÂ­
cord in music, a want of harmony beÂ­
tween the shawl and the glove on the
same person, a curt answer, a passing
slight, the wind from the east, any one
of ten thousand annoyances, opens the
door for the hornet. The fact is that
the vast majority of the people in this
country are overworked, and their
nerves are the first to give out. A
great multitude are under the strain of
Leyden, who, when he was told by his
physician that if he did not stop workÂ­
ing while he was in such poor physical
health he would die, responded, "DocÂ­
tor, whether I live or die, the wheel
must keep going round." These sensiÂ­
tive persons of whom I speak have a
bleeding sensitiveness. The flies love
to light on anything raw, and these
people are like the Canaanites spoken
of in the text or in the context-they
have a very thin covering and are vulÂ­
nerable at all points. "And the Lord
sent the hornet."
Again, the small insect annoyances
may come to us in the shape of friends
and acquaintances who are always sayÂ­
ing disagreeable things. There are
some people you cannot be with for
half an hour but you feel cheered and
comforted. Then there are other peoÂ­
ple you cannot be with for five minutes
before you feel miserable. They do not
mean to disturb you, but they sting
you to the bone. They gather up all
the yarn which the gossips spin and
retail it. Tlhey gather up all the adÂ­
verse criticisms about your person,
about your business, about your home,
about your church, and they make your
ear the funnel into which they pour it.
They laugh heartily when they tell
you, as though it were a good joke, and
you laugh, too-outside.
Job's Comxforters.
These people are brought to our atÂ­
tention In the Bible, In the book of
Ruth. Naomi went forth, beautiful
and with the finest of worldly prosÂ­
poets, into another land, but after
awhile she came back widowed and
sick and poor. What did her' friends
do when she came to the city?. They
all went out, and. instepd of giving her
common sense consolation, what did
they do? Rcad the boolk of Ruth and
find out. They threw up their hands
and said, "Is this Naomi?" as much as
to say, "How awful bad you do look!"
WVhen I entered the ministry, I looked
very pale for years, and every year,
for four or five years, many times a
year I was asked if I had not conÂ­
sumption, and, passing throughl tlhe
room, 1 would sometimes hear people
sigh and say. "A-ah, not long for this
world!" I resolved in those times that
I never in any conversation would say
anything depressing, and by the help
of God I have kept the resolution.
These people of whom I speak reap
and bind In the great harvest field of
discouragement. Some day you greet




 them with a hilarious "Good morning,"
and they come buzzing at you with
some depressing information; "The
Lord sent the hornet,"
It is astonishing how some people
prefer to write and to say disagreeable
things. That was the case when HenÂ­
ry M. Stanley returned after his magÂ­
nificent exploit of finding David LivÂ­
ingstone. When 'Mr. Stanley stood beÂ­
fore the savants of Europe and many
of. the small critics of the day, under
pretense of getting geographical inÂ­
formation, put to him most insolent
questions, he folded his arms and reÂ­
fused to answer. At the very time
when you would suppose all decent
men would have applauded the heroÂ­
islu of the man there were those to
hiss. "The Lord sent the hornet." And
when afterward that man sat down on
the western coast of Africa, sick and
worn out, with perhaps the grandest
achievement of the age in the way of
geographical discovery, there were
small critics all over the world to buzz
and buzz and caricature and deride
him, and when after awhile he got the
London papers, as he opened them,
out flew the hornet. When I see that
there are so many people in the world
who like to say disagreeable things
and write disagreeable things, I come
almost in my .weaker moments to beÂ­
lieve what a man said to me in PhilaÂ­
delphia one Monday morning. I went
to get the horse at the livery stable,
and the hostler, a plain man, said to
me, "Mr. Talmage, I saw that you
preached to the young men yesterday."
I said, "Yes." Hle said: "No use, no
use. Man's a failure."
Domestic Disturbances.
The small insect annoyances of life
sometimes come in the shape of local
physical trouble which does not
amount to a positive prostration, but
which bothers you when you want to
feel the best. Perhaps it is a sick
headache which has been the plague of
your life, and you appoint some occaÂ­
sion of mirth or sociality or usefulness,
and when the clock strikes the hour
you cannot make your appearance.
Perhaps the trouble is between the
ear and the forehead in the shape of
a neuralgic twinge. Nobody can see it
or sympathize with it, but just at the
time whenu you want your intellect
clearest and your disposition brightest
you feel a sharp, keen, disconcerting
thrust. "The Lord sent the hornet."
Perhaps these small insect annoyÂ­
ances will come in the shape of a doÂ­
mestic irritation. The parlor and the
kitchen do not always harmonize. To
get good service and to keep it is one of
the great questions of the country.
Sometimes it may be the arrogance
and inconsiderateness of employers;
but, whatever be the fact, we all admit
there are these insect annoyances
winging their way out from the culiÂ­
nary department. If the grace of God
be not in the heart of the housekeeper,
she cannot maintain her equilibrium.
The men come home at night and hear
the story of these annoyances and say,
"Oh, these home troubles are very litÂ­
tle things!" They are small, small as
wasps, but they sting. Martha's nerves
were all unstrung when she rushed in
asking Christ to scold Mary, and there
are tens of thousands of wonmen who
are dying, stung to death by these pesÂ­
tiferous domestic annoyances. "The
Lord sent the hornet."
These small insect disturbances may
also come in the shape of business irÂ­
ritations. There are men here who
went through the 24th of September,
1869, and the panics of 1873 and of
1803 without losing their balance who
are every day unhorsed by little anÂ­
noyances-a clerk's ill manners, or a
blot of ink on a bill of lading, or the
extravagance of a partner who overÂ­
draws his account, or the underselling
by a business rival, or the whispering
of store confidences in the street, or the
making of some little bad debt which
was against your judgment, but you
wanted to please somebody else.
It is not the panics that kill the merÂ­
chants. Panics come only once in 10 or
20 years. It is the constant din of these
everyday annoyances which is sending
so many of our best merchants into
nervous dyspepsia and paralysis and
the grave. When our national comÂ­
merce fell flat on its face, these men
stood up and felt almost defiant, but
their life is going away now under the
swarm of these pestiferous annoyÂ­
ances, "The Lord sent the hornet."
Keep on Moving.
I have noticed in the history of some
of my congregation that their annoyÂ­
ances are multiblying and that they
have a hundred where they used to
have ten. Time naturalist tells us that
a wasp sometimes has a family of 20,Â­
000 wasps, and it does seem as if evÂ­
ery annoyance of your life brooded a
million. By thie help of God, today I
want to show -you thie other side. Tihe
hornet is of no use? Oh, yes! The natÂ­
uralist tells us they are very important
in the world's economy. They kill spiÂ­
ders, and they clear the atmosphere.
And I really believe God sends thie anÂ­
noyances of our life upon us to kill the
spiders of thie soul anld to clear the atÂ­


These annoyances are sent on us, I
think, to wake us up from our letharÂ­
gy. There Is nothing that makes a
man so lively as a nest of "yellow jackÂ­
ets," and I think that these unnoyÂ­
ances are Intended to persuade us of
the fact that this is not a world for
us to stop In. If we had a bed of evÂ­
erything that was attractive and soft
and easy, what would we want of
heaven? We think that the hollow tree
sends the hornet, or we may think that
i the devil sends the hornet. I want to
correct your opinion. "The Lord sent
the hornet."
Then I think these annoyances come
on us to cultivate our patience. In the
gymnasinuml you fi(nd upright :arallel
bars with holes over each other for
pegs to be put In. Then the gymnast
takes a peg in each hand, and lie beÂ­
gins to climb, one inch at a time cr
two inches, and, getting his strength
cultivated, reaches after awhile the

 ceiling. And it seems to me that these
annoyances in life are a moral gymnaÂ­
sium, each worrlulent -. a peg with
which we are to climb higher and highÂ­
er in Christian attainment. We all love
to see patience, but It cannot be cultiÂ­
vated in fair weather. Patience is a
child of the storm. If you had everyÂ­
thing desirable and there was nothing
more to get, what would you want
with patience? The only time to cultiÂ­
vate it is when you are lied about and
sick and half dead.
"0h," you say, "if I only had the cirÂ­
cumstances of some well to do man I
would be patient too." Youi might as
well say, "If it were not for this waÂ­
ter, I would swim," or, "I could shoot
this gun if it were not for the carÂ­
tridge." When you stand chin deep
in annoyances is the time for you. to
swim out toward the great headlands
of Christian attainment, so as to
"know Christ and the power of his
resurrection and to have fellowship
with his sufferings."
Trust In Chrisnt.
Nothing but the furnace will ever
burn out of us the clinker and the slag.
I have formed this theory in regard to
small annoyances and vexations. It
takes just so much trouble to fit us for
usefulness and for heaven. The only
question is whether we shall take it in
the bulk or pulverized and granulated.
Here is one man who takes it in the
bulk. His back is broken or his eyeÂ­
sight put out, or some other awful caÂ­
lamity befalls him, while the vast maÂ­
jority of people take the thing pieceÂ­
meal. Which way would you rather
have it? Of course, in piecemeal.
Better have five aching teeth 'than
one broken jaw, better 10 fly blisters
than an amputation, better 20 squalls
than one cyclone. There may be a
difference of opinion as to allopathy
and homeopathy, but in this matter of
trouble I like homeopathic doses, small
pellets of annoyance rather than some
knockdown dose of calamity. Instead
of the thunderbolt give us the hornet.
if you have a bank, you would a great
deal rather that 50 men would come in
with checks less than $100 than to
have two depositors come in the same
day, each wanting his $10,000. In this
latter case you cough and look down
to the floor and you look up to the ceilÂ­
ing before you look into the safe. Now,
my friends, would you not rather have
these small drafts of annoyance on
your bank of faith than some all stagÂ­
gering demand upon your endurance?
But remember that little as well as
great annoyances equally require you
to trust in Christ for succor and for
deliverance from impatience and irritaÂ­
bility. "Thou wilt keep him in perfect
peace whose mind is staid on thee."
In the village of Hamuelin, tradition
says, there was an invasion of rats, and
these small creatures almost devoured
the town and threatened the lives of
the population, and the story is that a
piper came out one day and played a
very sweet tune, and all the vermin
followed him, followed him to the
banks of the Weser, and then he blew
a blast, and they dropped in and disÂ­
appeared forever. Of course this is a
fable; but I wish I could on the sweet
flute of the gospel draw forth all the
nibbling and burrowing annoyances of
your life and play them down into the
depths forever.
Aids to Spfritfldt Wenlth.
How many touches did Mr. Church
give to his picture of "Cotopaxkl" or his
"Heart of the Andes?" I suppose about
50,000 touches. I hear the canvas sayÂ­
ing: "Why do you keep me trembling
with that pencil so long? Why don't
you put it on in one dash?" "No," says

painting. It will take 50,000 of these

sand.annoyances which under God are

en, fit for angels to look at. God knows

cinated. Well, God has your soul under

der why some great providence does

tle troubles of life that are having

Mr. TRUMBULL gave notice of a bill to enlarge the powers
of the Freedmen's Bureau so as to secure freedom to all perÂ­
sons within the United States, and protect every individual
in the full enjoyment of the rights of person and property,
and furnish them the means of their vindication.
Mr. TRUMBULL. In giving this notice I desire to say it is
given in view of the adoptiou of the constitutional amend.
mont abolishing slavery. Whatever diversity of opinion there
may be as to the'actual adoption of the amendment at this
time, in consequence of the abnormal condition of some of the
State Legislatures which have ratified it, there can be no doubt
that it will soon, and probably before action could be had in
Congress, have the sanction of a sufficient number of States to
put its adoption beyond cavil. I have never doubted that
under the second section of the amendment it would be comÂ­
petent for Congress to protect every person within the lnited
States in all the rights of person and property belonging to a
free citizen; and to secure those rights is the object of the bill
I propose to introduce. I think it importaut that action should
bi taken on this subject at an early day, both for the purpose
of quieting apprehensions in the minds of many friends of
freedom, lest by local legislation or a prevailing public sentiÂ­
ment in some of the States, persons of the African race should
continue to be oppressed, and in fact deprived of a true freeÂ­
dom: and for the purpose of showing to those among whom
slavery has heretfore existed, that unless they by local legisÂ­
lation provide for the real freedom of their former slaves, the
Federal Government will, by virtue of its authority, see that
they are fully protected.

The message of the President was read, as follow s:
To the Senate oef te LSite;d States:
In reply to the resolution adopted by the Senate on the 12th
instant, 1 have the honor to state that the rebellion waged by
a portion of the people against the properly constituted anuÂ­
thority of the Government of the United. States has been supÂ­
pressed; that the United States are in possession of every
State in which the insurrection existed, and that, as far as it
could be done, the courts of the United States have been reÂ­
stored, post offices re.established, and steps taken to put into
effective operation the revenue laws of the country.
As the result of the measures instituted by the Executive,
with the view of inducing a resumption of the functions of the
States comprehended in the inquiry of the Senate, the people
of North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, MidosÂ­
sippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Tennessee have reorganized
their respective State governments, and " arevielding obedieace
to the laws and Government of the United dtatea," with more
willingness and greater promptitude than under the circumÂ­
stances could reasonably have been anticipated. The proposed
amendment of the Constitution, providing for the abolition of
slavery forever within the limits of the country, has been ratiÂ­
fled b each one of those States, with the exception of .MissisÂ­
..ippi, from whleh no official information has been received,
and in nearly all of them measures have been adopted, or are
now pending, to confer upon freedmen the privileges which
are essential to thmeir comfort, protection, and security. In
Florida and Texas the people are making commendahble proÂ­
gress in restoring their btate governments and no doubt is enÂ­
tertained that they will at an early period bo in a condition to
resume all of their practical relations with the General GovÂ­
ernment.
In "that portion of the Union lately in rebellion," the aspect
of affairs is more promising than, in view of all the circum.
stances, could wall have been expocted. The people throughÂ­
out the entire South evince a laudable desire to renew their
allogianco to the Government, and to repair the devastations
of war by a prompt and cheerful return to peaceful pursuits,
and abiding faith is entertained that their actions will conÂ­
form to their professions, and that in acknowledging the
supreuac~ o o thie Constitution and laws of the Unite~ States


ear lorauty will Do unreservely given to too ioverrnment,
whose leniency they cannot fail to appreciate, and whose fosÂ­
tering care will soon restore them to a condition of prosperity.
It is true that in some of the States the demoralizing effects of
the waar are to be seen in occasional disorders; but these are
local in character, not frequent in occurrence, and are rapidly
disappearing as the authority of civil law is extended and susÂ­
taines. Perplexing quasotrs are naturally to be expected
from the great and uaniden abuge in ttoe relations between the
two races; but systems are gradeualy developinug themselves
under which the freedman will receiVr the protection to which
he is ljuastly entitled, and, by means of his labor, make himself
a useful and independent member in the community in which
he has a home.
From all the information in my possession, and from that
which I have recently derived from the most reliable authoriÂ­
ty, I am induced to cherish the belief that sectional animosity
is surely and rapidly merging itself into a spirit of nationalityÂ­
and that representation, connected with a properly-adjusted a
system of taxation, will result in a harmonious restoration of
the relation of the States to the National Union.

HEADQUAnTERs ARMIES OF THE UNUTED STATEs,
WAsnmaxoso, D. C., December 18, 1865.
His Excellency A. Jo~hnon, residenlt of tle United State s:
Sin: In reply to your note of the 16tli instant requesting a i
report from me, giving such information as I may be possessed I
of, coming within the scope of the inquiries made by the SenÂ­ t
ate of the United States in their resolution of the 12th instant, a
I have the honor to submit the following: i
With your approval and also that of the honorable Secretary
of War, I left Washington city on the 27i of last month for 1
the purpose of maling a tour of inspectrio through some of
the Southern States, or States lately in rebellion, and to see t
what changes were necessary to be made in the disposition of
the military forces of the country, how these forces could be
reduced, and expenses curtailed, etc., and to learn as far as posÂ­ c
sible the feelings and intentions of the citizens of those States
towards the General GoVernment. The State of Virginia beÂ­ I
ng so accessiblo to Washington city, and information from
this quarter, therefore, being readily obtained, I hastened I
through the State without conversing or meeting with any of r
its citizens. In Raleigh, N'. C., I spent.one day; in Charleston, f
S. C.,two days; Savannah and Augusta, Georgia, each one I
day. Both in travelling and whilst stopping, I saw much and
conversed freely with the eitIzens of those States, as well as
with officers of the army who have been stationed among them. a
The fbllowng are the conclusions come to by me t a
I am satihedd that the mass of thinking men of the South
accept the present situation of affairs in good faith. The ques. f
tions which have heretofore divided the sentiments of the peeoÂ­ t
pie of the two sectlons-slavery and State rigbts-or the right c
of a State to secedefrm the Union--they regard as having
been settled fomrever by the highest trlhunal-arm-sthat man
can resort to. I was pleased to learn from the leading men
whom Imet that they not only accepted the decision arrived I
at as final, but that now the smoke ofl battle hs cleared away c
and time has been given for reflection, that this decision has I
been a fortunate one for the whole country, they reoeiving the i
like benefits form it with those who opposed' thm in the field I
and in the cuose.
Four yesrs of war, during which law was executed only at i
the point of the ayounet thronghot..the:States .in rebellion, t
have left the people, po.ably, In eotditlon not to yield that
zeadyobedlene ii civltor the Anerlcan poenople have I
enmy beenin the habit o yfeidin -This would render I
espresnce of nrgaro th hut thoeostatsanoe-. I




 sary until such time as labor retuorn tSalts aper channel and
civil authority is fully established I did not meet any one,
either those liolding places under the Governmment or citizens
of the Bouthern States, who think it practicable to withdraw
the military from the South at present. The white and the
black mutually require the protection of the General GovernÂ­
ment.
There is such univeraal acquiescence to the authority of the
General Government throughout the portions of the country
visited by me, thgt the mere presence of a military force,
without regard to numbers, is asfclent tomaintain order. The
good of the country, and economy, require that the force kept
in the interior where there are many freedmen (elsewhere, in
the Southern States, than at forts upon the sea-coast no force
is necessary) should all be white troops. The reasons for this
are obvious, without mentioning any of them. The presence
of black troops, lately slaves, demoralizes labor, both-by their
advice, and by furnishing in their camps a resort for the freedÂ­
men for long distances around. White troops generally excite
no opposition, and, therefore, a small number of them can
maintain order in a given district. Colored troops must be
kept in Jodies sufficient to defend themselves. It is not the
thinking men who would use violence towards any class of
troops sent among them by the General Government, but the
ignorant in some places might; and the late slave seems to be
imbued with the idea that the property of his late master
should by right belong to him-at least, should have no proÂ­
tection from the colored soldiers. There is danger of colliÂ­
elons being brought on by such causes.
My observations lead me to the conclusion that the citizens
of the Southern States are anxioas to return to self-government
within the Union as soon as possible; that whilst reconstructÂ­
ing, they want and require protection from the Government;
that they are in earnest In wishing to do what they think is
required by the Government-not humiliating to them as citiÂ­
zens-and that if such a course was pointed out, they would
pursue it in good-faith. It is to be regretted that there canÂ­
not be a greater commingling at this time between the citizens
of the two sections, and particularly of those entrusted with
the law-making power.
I did not gave the operations of the Freedmen's Bureau that
attention I would have done if more time had been at my disÂ­
posal. Conversationson the subject, however, with oflicerscon
nected with the Bureau, lead me to think that In some of the
States its affairs have not been conducted with good Judgment
or economy and that the belief, widely spread among the
freedmen of the Southern States, that the lands of their former
owners will at least in part be divided among them, has come
from the agents of this Bureau. This belief is seriously interÂ­
fering with the willingness of the freedmen to make contracts
for the coming year. In some form the Freedmen's Bureau is
an absolute necessity until civil law is established and enforced,
securing to the freedmen their rights and folkprotection. At
present, however, it is independent of the military establishÂ­
ment of the country, and seems to be operated by the different
agents of the Bureau according to their individual notions.
Everywhere General Howard, the able head of the BuÂ­
reau, made friends by the just and fair instructions
and advice he "gave; but the complaint in South
Carolina was, that when he left things went on as before.
Many, perhaps the majority of the agents of the Freedmen's
Bureau, advise the freedmen that by their own industry they
must expect to live. To this end they endeavor to secure emÂ­
ployment for them, and to see that both contracting parties
comply with their engagements. In some instances, I am
sorry to say, the freedman's mind does not seem to be disaÂ­
bused of tito idea that the freedman has a right to live withÂ­
out care or provision for the future. The effect of the belief in
division of land is idleness and accumulation in camps towns,
and cities. In such cases I think it will be found that vice
and disease will tend to the extermination or great reduction
of the colored race. It cannot be expected that the opinions
held by men at the South for years can be changed in a day,
and therefore the freedmen require for a few years not only
laws to protect them, but the fostering care of those who will
give them good counsel and in whom they rely.
The Freedmen's Bureau, being separated from the military
establishment of the country, acquires all the expense of a
separate organization. One does not necessarily know what
the other is doing, or what order they are acting under. It
seems to me this could be corrected by regarding every.officer
on duty with troops in the Southern States as agents of the
Freedmen's Bureau, and then have all orders from the head of
the Bureau sent through department commanders. This would
create a responsibility that would secure uniformitr of action
throughout the South, would insure the orders anid instrucÂ­
tions from the head of the Bureau being carried out, and would
relieve from duty and pay a large number of employds of the
Government.

The Fourteen Mistakes of Life.
An exchange says that somebody has
condensed the mistakes of life and arÂ­
rived at the conclusion that there are
fourteen of them. Most people would
say, if they told the truth, that there is
no limit to the mistakes of life; that
they are like drops in the ocean, or the
sands on the shore in number; but it is
as well to be accurate. Here, then, are
fourteen great mistakes: (1) It is a
great mistake to set up our own standÂ­
ard of right and wrong, and judge peoÂ­
ple accordingly. (2) It is a great misÂ­
take to measure the enjoyment of othÂ­
ers by our own. (3) It is a great misÂ­
take to expect uniformity of opinion in
this world. (4) It is a great mistake to
look for judgment and experience in
youth. (5) It is a great mistake to enÂ­
deavor to mold all dispositions alike.
(6) It is a great mistake not to yield to
immaterial trifles. (7) It is a great
mistake to look for perfection in our
own actions. (8) It is a great mistake
to worry ourselves and others with
what can not be remedied. (9) It is a
great mistake not to alleviate all that
needs alleviation, as, far as lies in our
power. (10) It is a great mistake not
to make allowance for the infirmities
of others. (11) It is a great mistake to
consider everything impossible that
we can not perform. (12) It is a great
mistake to believe only what our finite
minds can grasp. (13) It is a great
mistake to expect to be able to underÂ­
stand everything. (14) The greatest
of mistakes is to live for time alone,
when any moment may launch us into
eternity.-Star.

teen may bring in with him, or send for,

posing a $10 head tax on immigrants comÂ­

YOUNG MEN--BUSINESS MEN.
It is easier to be a good business man
than a poor one. Half of the energy disÂ­
played in keeping ahead as is required in
catching up when behind will save credit,
give more time to attend to business, and
add to the profits and reputation of those
who work for gain. Be prompt. Keep your
word. Honor your engagements. If you
promise to meet a man or do a certain thing
at a certain moment be ready at the appoinÂ­
ted time. If you have work to doâ€”do it at
once, cheerfully and theiefore speedily and
correctly. If you go out on business, atÂ­
tend promptly to the matter at hand, then
as promptly go about your business. Do
not stop to tell stories in business hours.
If vou have a place of business, be found
there when wanted. No man can get rich
by sitting around saloons, playing old sledge
euchre, peanuekle, or other games for whisÂ­
ky. Never "fool" on business matters. If
you have to labor for a living, remember
that one hour in the morning is better than
two at night. If you employ others, be on
hand to see that they attend to their duties,
and to direct work to an advantage. Have
orderâ€”systemâ€”regularityâ€”promptnessâ€”
liberality. Do not meddle witli business you
know nothing of. Whatever you do, do
well. Never buy an article simply because
the man who sells will take it out in trade.
Trade is money. Time is money. A good
business habit and reputation are always
money. Make your place of business pleasÂ­
ant and attractive, then stay there to wait
on customers. Never use quick words or
allow yourself to make hasty and ungentleÂ­
manly remarks to those in your employ, for
to do so lessons their respect for you, and
your influence over them. Help yourself
and others will help you. Be faithful over
the interests confided in jour keeping, and
all in good time your responsibility will be
incrcascd-

Do not be in too great baste to get rich.
Do not build till you have arranged and laid
a good foundation. Do not, as you hope or
work for success, spend time in loafing, if
your time is your own, business will surely
suffer if you do. If it Is given to another
for payj it belongs to him, and you have no
more right to steal it than you have to steal
money. Be obliging. Strive to avoid harsh
words and personalities. Do nut kick every
stone in the path. More miles can be made
in a day by going steadily on than by stopÂ­
ping to kick. Day as you go. A man of
honor respects his word "as he does his bond.
Ask but never beg. Help others when you
can without convenience to yourself. But
never give when you cannot afford to, simÂ­
ply because it is fashionable. Learn to say
no. No necessity of snapping it out dog
fashion, but firmly and respectfully. Have
but few confidants. The fewer the better.
Use your own brains rather than others.
Learn to think and act for yourself. Be
honest. Be vigilant. Be active and liberal.
Keep ahead, rather than behind the times.
Young manâ€”cut this out, and if there is
folly in the argument let us know.
The above rules have done us good servÂ­
ice, and arc given as hints to the young men
of the country who must he either loafers
or gentlemen, business men or bankrupts,
respected or uncared for, as they themselves
may determine.â€”Brick Pomeroy.

soon put an end to the troubles aud disorÂ­
ders in that State.
General Sheridan was looking at facts,
nnd possibly not thinking of proceedings,
which would be the only proper ones to
pursue in time of peace, thought more of
tha utterly lawless condition of society
surrounding him at the time of his dispatch,
aud of what would be a sure remedy. He
never proposed to do an illegal act, nor exÂ­
pressed a determination to proceed beyond
what the law in the future might authorize
for the punishment oi the atrocities which
have been committed, anil tho commission
of which can not be successfully denied.
It is a deplorable fact that political crimes
and murders have been committed in LouÂ­
isiana which have gone unpunished, and
such have been justified or apologized for
which must rest as a reproach upon the
State and country long after the present
generation lias passed away.
I have no desire to have United State#
troous interfere in the domestic concerns of
ot Louisiana or any other State. On the
ninth of December last Governor Kellogg
telegrapned to me hi# apprehensions that
the White League intendi-d to make another
attack upon the State House, to which on
the same day I made the following answer,
since which no communication ha# been
sent to him: "Your dispatch of this date
just received. It is exceedingly unpalatable
to use troops iu anticipation of danger. Let
the State authorities be right and then proÂ­
ceed with their duties without apprehension
of danger. If they are then molested, the
requisition will be determined whether the
United States is urahle to maintain law and
order within its limits, or not." I have deÂ­
plored the necessity which seemed to make
it my duty under the constitution and laws
to direct such interference. I have always
refused, except where it seemed to be
my imperative duty to act in such a
manner under tlie constitution and tbe
laws of Congress. I have repeatedly and
earnestly entreated the people of the South
to iive together in peac- aud obey tbe laws,
and nothing would give me greater pleasure
than to see reconciliation and tranquillity
everywhere prevail, and thereby remove
all necessity for the presence of troops
among them. I regret, however, to say
that this state of things does not exist,
nor does its existence seem to bo desired
in some localities: and, as to those, it may
be proper for me to say that to the extent
that Congress has conferred power upon
me to prevent it. neither Ku Klux Klans,
White Leagues nor any other association
using arms and violence to execute their
unlawful purpose can be permitted ia that
way to govern any part oi this country.
Nor can I see with indifference Union
men or Republicans ostracised, persecuted
and murdered on account of their opinions,
a9 they are now in gome localities.
1 have heretofore urged the case of LouÂ­
isiana upon the attention of Congress, and
can not but think that its inaction has proÂ­
duced great evil. To summarize : In SepÂ­
tember last an organized body of men in
the support of candidates who had been
put in nomination for the offices of GovÂ­
ernor aud Lieutenant Governor at the NoÂ­
r-ember election in 1872. an-1 who hail been
declared not elected by tha board of canÂ­
vassers. recognized by all the courts to
which the question had been submitted, unÂ­
dertook to subvert and overthrow the State
government that had been recognized by
me in accordance with previous precedents.
Tlie recognized Governor was driven from
the Stab- House; and but for his finding
shelter in the United States Customhouse,
in the capita! of the State of which he was
Governor, it is scarcely to be doubted that
be would have been killed. From the S'ate
Honse, before he had been driven to the CusÂ­
tomhouse, a call was made in accordance
with the fourth section, fourth article of
the constitution of the United States, for
aid of the general government to suppress
domestic violence. Under these circumÂ­
stances and in accordance with my sworn
duties, my proclamation of the fifteenth of
September was issued. This served to
reinstate Governor Kellogg to his position,
but it can not be claimed that the insurgents
have to this day surrendered to the State
authorities the arms belonging to the State,
or that they have in any sense disarmed.
On the contrary, it iÂ» known that the same
armed organization that existed on tbe
fourteenth oi September, 1874, ffi opposition

to tbe recognized State government, still
retain its organization, equipments and
commandors, and can be called oat any
hour to resist the State government.
Under these circumstances the same miliÂ­
tary force has been continued in Louisiana
as was sent there under the first call and
under the same general instructions. I
repeat that the task ag^med by the troops
is uot a pleasant one tc vheui: that the army
is not composed of lawyers capable of judgÂ­

order, and that it was impossible to give

the commanding officer upon each sudden
contingency that arose, or the instructions
whicli could only reach them after the
threatened wrongs had been committed
which tbev were called on to prevent.
It should be recollected, too. that upon
my recognition of the Kellogg I reported
the fact, with the grounds ot recognition, to
Congress, and asked that body to take
action in the matter; otherwise I should
regard their silence as acquiescence in my
course. No action has beea taken by that
body. If error ha# been committed by the

on tbe side of the preservation of good
order, the maintaining of law and the proÂ­
tection of life. Their bearing reflects credit
upon the soldiers, and if wrong has resulted,

action be taken by Congress as to leave my
duties perfectly clear iu dealing with affairs
in Louisiana, giving assurance at the same
time tha' whatever may be done by that

cording to the Bpirit and letter of the law,
without fear or favor.

TexT-Who can find a virtuous woman?
for her price is far above rubies.-Solomon.
As virtuous women have in our days beÂ­
come as plenty as they were rare in the days
of Solomon, we can easily test the accuracy
of his description, detecting Iris inaccuracies,
and observing how they are intermin2led with
correct description, of which we subjoin the
following instances:
"She seeketh wool and flax, and worketh
willingly with her hands."
Hired laborers are technically denominated
"hands," and so are the slaves on the other
side of the river. The inaccuracy in the above
account consists in the use of the term
"hands," for servants of both sexes, it being
generally confined to the males. The correct
portion of the description is, that the virtuous
woman is willing that her "hands," or eer
vants, should do her work.
"She is like the merchant's ship-she
bringeth her food from afar.
This simile has generally been considered
very correct. Merchant ships usually carry
small burdens in proportion as they are swift
sailing and stylishly rigged; and the more
expensive and beautiful they are, the less
profitable are they. "Her food is brought
from afar;" that is to say, her tea comes
from China, .re sugar from the West Indies,




 and her olher luxuries from all parts of tile
world.
"She rises also while it is yet night, and
giveth meat to her household, and a portion
to her maidens.
There is a little incorrectness here, which
mtay, perhaps, be in the translation. 'rhe
true meaning of the verse probably is, that
the virtuous woman, when she gives a party,
sits up all night, and gives a supper to her
visitlrs, allowing her maidens to eat a portion
after them.
"She considereth a field and buyeth it;
with the fruit of Iher hands she planteth a vinÂ­
yard."
'That is to say, the virtuous woman being
occasionally tired of town, persuades her husÂ­
band to buy a country seat, and by the labor
of her hired hands, to ornament it with "vines
and fruit trees."
"She girdeth herfloins with strength, and
strengtheneth her arms."
This is strictly correct. The virtuous woÂ­
man requires a strong girdle around tier loins,
in order to make her waist as small as fashion
requires; and she must strengthen her arms
in order to draw hier girdle as tight as necesÂ­
sary.
"She perceiveth that ther merchandise is
good; her candle goethr not out by night."
That is, when she goes a shopping, she
examines an immense quantity of goods, for
the purpose of being sure that they are of the
best quality, before she makes a purchase.
Her candle, of course, cannot go out by night
whether she gives a party or goes to one.
"She layeth her hands to the spindle, and
lher hands hold the distaff."

handful of borax powder to about ten galÂ­
lons of boiling water; they save in soap
nearly half. All the large washing estabÂ­
lishments adopt the same mode. For-laces,
cambrics, &c., an extra quantity of powder
is used, and for crinolines, (required to be
made very stiff,) a strong solution is necessaÂ­
ry. Borax being a neutral salt, does not in
the slightest. degree injure the texture of the
linen; its cifect is to soitecn the hardest waÂ­
ter, and therefore it should be kept on every
toilet table. To the taste it is rather sweet,
and is used for cleaning the hair, is an exÂ­
cellent dentrifice, and in hot countries is used
in combination with tartaric acid and bicarÂ­
bonie of soda as a cooling beverage. Good
tea cannot be made with hard water; all
water may be made soft by adding a teaÂ­
spoonful of borax powder to an ordinary
sized kettle of water, in which it should
boil. The savinig in quantity of tea used
will at least one-fifth. To give black tea
the flavor of green tea, add a single leaf
from the black currant tree.

S TARIFF.
It is now quite evident that the financial necessities
e of the Government will require a modification of the
it
tariff during your present session, for the purpose of
increasing the revenue. In this aspect, I desire to
reiterate the recommendation contained in my last
two annual messages, in favor of imposing specific
instead of ad ralerces duties on all imported articles
to which these can be properly applied. From long
e observation and experience I am convinced that speÂ­
*r
cific duties are necessary, both to protect the revenue
and to secure to our manufacturing interests that
e amount of incidental encouragement which unavoidÂ­
ably results from a revenue tariff.
t As an abstract proposition it may be admitted that
ad valorem duties would, in theory, be the most just
and equal. But if the experience of this and all othÂ­
ercommercisl nations has demonstrated that such
duties cannot be assessed and collected without great
n
frauds upon the revenue, then it is the part of wisÂ­
0 dom to resort to specific duties. Indeed, from the
o very nature of an ad aloremr duty, this must be the
- result. Under it the inevitable consequence is, that
r foreign goods will be entered at less than their true
,f value. The treasury will, therefore, lose the duty on
the difference between their real and fictitious value,
and to this extent we are defrauded.
The temptations which ad valorem duties present
to a dishonest importer are irresistible. His object
is to pass his goods through the custom-house at the
very lowest valuation necessary to save them from
confiscation. In this he too often succeeds in spite
t of the vigilance of the revenue officers. Hence the
, resort to false invoices, one for the purchaser and anÂ­
1
other for the custom-house, and to other expedients
to defraud the Government. The honest importer
produces his invoice to the collector, stating the acÂ­
tual price at which he purchased the articles abroad.
Not so the dishonest importer and the agent of the
foreign manufacturer. And here it may be observed
that a very largs, proportion of the manufactures imÂ­
ported from abroad are consigned for sale to commisÂ­
sion merchants who are mere agents employed by the
manufacturers. In such cases no actual sale has
been made to fix their value. The foreign manufacÂ­
turer, if he be dishonest, prepares an invoice of the
goods, not at their actual value, but at the very lowÂ­
est rate necessary to escape detection. In this manÂ­
ner the dishonest importer and the foreign manufacÂ­
turer enjoy a decided advantage over the honest merÂ­
chant. They are thus enabled to undersell the fair traÂ­
der, and drive him from the market. In fact, the
operation of this system has already driven from the
pursuits of honorable commerce many of that class
of regular and conscientious merchants, whose charÂ­
acter, throughout the world, is the pride of our counÂ­
try.
The remedy for these evils is to be found in specific
duties, so far as this may be practicable. They disÂ­
pense with any inquiry at the custom-house into the
actual cost or value of the article, and it pays the preÂ­
cise amount of duty previously fixed by law. They
present no temptations to the appraisers of foreign
goods, who receive but small salaries, and might, by r
undervalue on in a few cases, render themselves inÂ­
dependant.
Besides, specific duties best conform to the requisiÂ­
tion in the Constitution that "no preference shall be 1
given by any regulation of commerce or revenue to
the ports of one State over tlose of another." Under
our ad valorem system such preferences are to some r
extent inevitable, and complaints have often been X
made that the spirit of this provision has been vioÂ­
lated by a lower appraisement of the same articles at
one port than at another.
An impression strangely enough prevails to some
extent that specific duties are necessarily protective
duties. Nothing can be more fallacious. Great 2
Britain glories in free trade, and yet her whole roveÂ­
nue from imports is at the present moment collected
under a system of specific duties. It is a striking fact
in this connection that, in the commercial treaty of
23d January, 1860, between France and England, one
of the articles provides that the ad caloremn duties
which it imposes shall be converted into specific duÂ­
ties within six months from its date, and these are to
be ascertained by making an average of the prices for
six months previous to that time. The reverse of the
proposition would be nearer to the truth, because a
much larger amount of revenue would be collected by
merely converting the ad valtoreus duties of a tariff
into equivalent specific duties. To this extent the
revenue would be increased, and in the same proporÂ­
tion the specific duty might be diminished.
Specific duties would secure to the American manÂ­
ufacturer the incidental protection to which he is
fairly entitled under a revenue tariff, and to this sureÂ­
ly no person would object. The framers of the exisÂ­
ting tariff have gone fitrther, and in a liberal spirit
have discrimninated in favor of large and useful
branches of our manufactures, not by raising the rate
of duty upon the importation of similar articles from
abroad, but what is the same in effect, by admitting (
articles free of duty which enter into the composition


i at uneir arlics.
Under the present system it has been often truly
remarked that this incidental protection decreases
when the manufacturer needs it most, and increases
when he needs it least, and c nstitutes a sliding scale
which always operates against him. The revenues of 1
the country are subject to similar fluctuation. InÂ­ t
stead of approaching a steady standard, as would be
the case under a system of specific duties, they sink
and rise with the sinking and rising prices of articles
in foreign countries. It would not be difficult for
Congress to arrange a system of specific duties which
would afford additional stability both to our revenue
and our manufactures, and without injury or injustice -
to any interest of the country. This might be accomÂ­
plished by ascertaining the average value of any givÂ­
en article for a series of years at the place of exportaÂ­
tion, and by simply converting the rate of ad valorem
duty upon it which might be deemed necessary for i
revenue purposes, into the form of a specific duty.Â­
Such an arrangement could not injure the consumer.
If he should pay a greater amount of duty one year,
this would be counterbalanced by a lesser amount
the next, and in the end the aggregate would be the
same.

                 which tells the length of the longest day in sev-eral places. How unfortunate are the childrenin Tornea, Finland, where Christmas Day is less. than three hours in length!
                 At Stockholm. Sweden, it is eighteen and one half hours in length.
                 At Spitzbergen the longest day is three and one half months.
                 At London, England, and Bremen, , the longest day has sixteen and one half hours.
                 At Hamburg, Germany, and Dantzic, Prussia, the longest day has seventeen hours.
                 At Wadbury, Norway, the longest day lasts from May 21 to July 22, without interruption.
                 At St. Petersburg, Russia, and Tobolsk, Siberia, the longest day is nineteen hours, and the shortest five hours.

Nicaragua for pecuniary indemnity, which
upon Nicaragua's refusal to admit liaÂ­
bility was enforced by Great Britain.
While the sovereignty and jurisdiction of
Nicaragua was in no way questioned by
Great Britain, the former's arbitrary conÂ­
duct in regard to British subjects furnishÂ­
ed the ground for this proceeding.
A British naval force occupied without
resistance the Pacific seaport of Corinto,
but was soon afterward withdrawn upon
the promise that the sum demanded would
be paid. Throughout this incident the
kindly offices of the United States were
invoked and were employed in favor of
a peaceful settlement and with as much
consideration and indulgence toward
Nicaragua as were consistent with the
nature of the case. These efforts have
since been made the subject of appropriate
and grateful recognition by Nicaragua.
RUSSIAN MATTERS.
The coronation of the czar of Russia at
Moscow in May next invites the cereÂ­
monial participation of the United States
and in accordance with usage and diploÂ­
matic propriety, our minister to the imÂ­
perial court has been directed to repÂ­
resent our government on this occasion.
Correspondence is on foot touching the
practice of Russian consuls within the
jurisdiction of the United States to interÂ­
rogate citizens as to their race and reÂ­
ligious faith and upon ascertainment
thereof to deny to Jews authentication
of passports or legal documents for use
in Russia may be found to infringe the
treaty rights of our citizens and which is
an obnoxious invasion of our territorial
jurisdiction, it has elicited a fitting remonÂ­
strance, the result of which it is hoped
will remove the cause of complaint.
The pending claim of sealing vessels
of the United States seized in Russian
waters remain unadjusted. Our recent
convention with Russia establishing a
modus vivendi as to imperial jurisdiction
in such cases has prevented further difÂ­
ficulty of this nature. The Russian govÂ­
ernment has welcomed in principle our
suggestion for a modus vivendi to embrace
Great Britain and Japan looking to the
better preservdtion of seal life in the
North Pacific and Bering seas and the
extension of the protected area defined by
the Paris tribunal to all Pacific waters
north of the 35th parallel.
It is especially noticeable that RusÂ­
sia favors prohibition of the use of the
firearms in seal hunting throughout the
proposed area and a longer closed seaÂ­
son for pelagic sealing.
AS TO SAMOA.
In my last two annual messages I called
the attention of the congress to the posiÂ­
tion we occupy as one of the parties to a
treaty or agreement by which we became
jointly bound with England and Germany
to so interfere with the government and
control Samoa as in effect to assume the
management of its affairs. On the 9th of
May, 1894, I transmitted to the senate a
special message with accompanying docuÂ­
ments giving information on the subject
and emphasizing the opinion I have at all
time entertained that our situation in this
matter was inconsistent with the mission
and traditions of our government, in vioÂ­
lation of the principles we profess and
in all its phases, mischievous and vexaÂ­
tious. I again press this subject upon the
attention of congress and ask for such
legislative action or expression as will
lead the way to our relief from obligaÂ­
tions both irksome and unnatural.
AN INSURRECTION ON CUBAN SOIL
Neutrality l.aws Must Be Observed, No
Matter What Grievance There Is.
Cuba is again gravely disturbed. An
insurrection, in one respect, more active
than the last preceding revolt which conÂ­
tinued from 1868 to 1878 now exists in a
large part of the eastern interior of the
island, menacing even some of the popuÂ­
lation on the coast. Besides deranging
the commercial exchanges of the island,
of which our country takes the predomiÂ­
nant share, this flagrant condition of hosÂ­
tilities, by arousing sentimental sympathy
and Inciting adventurous support among
our people, has entailed earnest effort on
the part of this government to enforce
obedience to our neutrality laws and to
prevent the territory of the United
States from being abused as a vantage
ground from which to aid those bearing
arms against Spanish sovereignty.
Whatever may be ~the traditional symÂ­
pathy of our countrymen as individuals
with a people who seem to be struggling
for larger autonomy and greater freedom,
and depend, as such sympathy naturally
must, on behalf of our neighbors, yet the
plain duty of their government is to obÂ­
sen-rve in good faith the recognized obliÂ­
gations of international relationship. The
performance of this duty should not be
made more difficult by a disregard on the
Spart of our citizens of the obligations
growing out of their allegiance to their
I country, which should restrain them from
violating as individuals the neutrality
which the nation of which they are memÂ­
bers is bound to observe in its relations
to friendly sovereign states. Though
neither the wa"rmth of our people's sym

pathy with the Cuban Insurgents, nor the
loss nor material damage consequent upon
the futile endeavors thus far made
to restore peace and order, or any shock
our humane sensibility may have received
from the cruelties which appear to especiÂ­
ally characterize this sanguinary and
fiercely conducted war, have in the least
shaken the determination of the governÂ­
ment to honestly fulfill every international
obligation, yet it is to be earnestly hoped
on every ground that the devastation of
armed conflict may speedily be stayed
and order and quiet restored to the disÂ­
tracted island, bringing into their train
the activity and thrift of peaceful purÂ­
suits.
ALLIANCA INCIDENT.
One notable instance of interference
by Spain with passing American ships has
occurred. On March 8, last, the Allianca,
while bound from Colon to New York, and
following the customary track for vessels
near the Cuban shore, but outside the
three-mile limit, was fired upon by a SpanÂ­
ish gunboat. Protest was promptly made
by the United States against this act as
not being justified by a state of war, nor
permissable in respect to vessels on the
usual paths of commerce, nor tolerable in
view of the wanton peril occasioned to
innocent life and property. The act was
disavowed, with full expression of reÂ­
gret, and assurance of non-recurrence of
such just cause of complaint, while the
offending officer was relieved of his comÂ­
mand.
Military arrests of citizens of the United
States in Cuba have occasioned frequent
reclamations. 1Where held on criminal
charges their delivery to the ordinary
civil jurisdiction for trial has been deÂ­
manded and obtained in conformity with
treaty provisions and where merely deÂ­
tained by way of military precaution unÂ­
der a proclaimed state of seige without
formulated accusation their release or
trial has been insisted upon. The right of
American consular officers on the island
to prefer protests and demands in such
cases having been questioned by the inÂ­
sular authorities, their enjoyment of the
privilege stipulated by treaty for the conÂ­
suls of Germany was claimed under the
most favored nation provision of our own
convention and was promptly recognized.
MORA CLAIM.
The long standing demand of Antonio
Maximo Mora against Spain has at last
been settled by the payment, on the 14th
of September last, of the sum originally
agreed upon in liquidation of the claim.
Its distribution among the parties entitled
to receive it has proceeded as rapidly as
the rights of those claiming the fund
could be safely determined.
The enforcement of differential duties
against products of this counlltry exported
to Cuba and Puerto Itico prompted the
immediate claim on our part to the beneÂ­
fit of the minimum tariff of Spain in reÂ­
turn for the most favorable treatment
permitted by our laws as regards to proÂ­
duction of Spanish territories. A comÂ­
mercial arrangement was concluded in
January last securing the treatment so
claimed.
Vigorous protests against excessive
fines imposed on our merchandise by the
customs officers of these islands for triÂ­
vial errors have resulted in the remission
of such fines in instances where the equity
of the complaint was apparent, though the
vexatious practice has not been wholly
discontinued.
OUR MISSIONARIES IN TUIIKEY

American Consuls Have Done Their UtÂ­
most to Protect Them.
Advices from Turkey have continued to
excite the people concerning the reported
massacres of Christians in Armenia and
the development there and in other disÂ­
tricts of a spirit of fanatical hostility to
Christian influences naturally excited ap
prehension for the safety of the devoted
men and women who, as dependents of
the foreign missionary societies in the
United States, reside In Turkey under the
guarantee of law and usage and in the
legitimate performance of their educaÂ­
tional and religious mission. No efforts
have been spared in their behalf and their
protection in person and property has
been earnestly and vigorously enforced by
every means within our power. I regret,
however, that an attempt on our part to
obtain better information concerning the
true condition of affairs in the disturbed
quarters of the Ottoman empire by sendÂ­
ing thither the United States consul at
Sivas to make investigation and the report
was thwarted by the objections of the
Turkish government. This government
on our part was in no sense meant as a
gratuitous entanglement of the United
States in the so-called eastern question,
nor as an officious interference with the
right and duty which belong by treaty to
certain great European powers, which
called for their intervention in political
matters affecting the good government
and religious freedom of the non-MusselÂ­
man subjects of the sultan, but it arose
solely from our desire to have an accurate
knowledge of the conditions in our efforts
to care for those entitled to our protection.
The presence of our naval vessels, which
are now in the vicinity of the disturbed
territories, affords opportunity to acquire
a measure of familiarity with the condiÂ­
tion of affairs, and will enable us to take
suitable steps for the protection of any inÂ­
terests of our countrymen within reach of
our ships that might be found imperilled.
The Ottoman government has lately isÂ­
sued an imperial tirade exempting forever
from taxation any American college for
girls at Scutari. Repeated assurances
have also been obtained by our envoy at
Constantinople that similar institutions
maintained and administered by our counÂ­
trymen shall be secured in the enjoyment
,f all rights and that our citizens throughÂ­
out the empire shall be protected.
The government, however, in view of
cxisting facts, is far from relying upon
such assurances as the limit of its duty.
)ur minister has been vigilant and alert
in affording all possible protection in inÂ­
dividual cases where danger threatened
or safety was imperilled. We have sent
ships as far toward the points of actual
disturbance as it is possible for them to
go, where they offer refuge to those obligÂ­
,d to flee and we have the promise of
-ther powers which have ships in the
neighborhood that our citizens, as well as
their citizens, will be received and protectÂ­
od on board those ships.
On the demand of our ministers orders
,ave been issued by the sultan that TurkÂ­
sh soldiers shall guard and escort to the
roist American refugees. Those orders
h,ave been carried out, and our latest inÂ­
elligence gives assurance of the present
rersonal safety of our citizens and misÂ­
ionaries. Though thus far no lives of
American citizens have been sacrificed,
there can be no doubt that serious loss
and destruction of mission property have
resulted from riotous conflicts and outÂ­
rageous attacks.
By treaty several of the most powerful
European powers have secured a right
and have assumed a duty not only in beÂ­
half of their own citizens and in furthÂ­
crance of their own interests, but as
agents of the Christian world. Their right
.s to enforce such conduct of the Turkish
government as will restrain fanatical
brutality and if this fails their duty is to
so interfere as to insure against such
dreadful occurences in Turkey as have
lately shocked civilization. The powers
declare this right and this duty to be
theirs alone, and it is earnestly hoped
that prompt and effective action on their
part will not be delayed.
The consulates at Erzeroum and agents
at Erzeroum and Karpout, for which apÂ­
propriation was made last session, have
been previously filed by trusted employes
of the department of state. These apÂ­
pointees, though now in Turkey, have not
received their exequators.

THE MESSAGE.
To tie Senate and House of Representatives:





Since the convening of Congress one year
ago the nation has undergone a prostration in
business and industries such as has not been
witnessed with us for many years. SpeculaÂ­
tion as to the causes for this prostration might
be indulged in without profit, because as many
theories would be advanced as there would be
independent writers-those who expressed
their own views without borrowing-upon the
subject. Without indulging in theories as to
the cause of this prostration, therefore I will
call your attention only to the fact, and to
some questions as to which it would seem there
should he no disagreement. During this prosÂ­
tration two essential elements of prosperity
have been most abundant-labor and capital.
Both have been largely unemployed. Where
security has been undoubted, capital has been
attainable at very moderate rates. Where labor
has been wanted, it has been found in abundÂ­
ance at cheap rates, comparing what the necesÂ­
saries and comforts of life could be purchased
with the wages demanded. Two great eleÂ­
ments of prosperity, therefore, have not been
denied us. A third might be. added. Our soil
and climate are unequaled, within the limits of
any contiguous territory under one nationality,
for its varieties of produce to feed and clothe a
people, and an amount of surplus to spare to
feed less favored people. Therefore, with these
facts in view, it seems time that wise statesmanÂ­
ship at this session of Congress would dictate
ignoring the past, distributing in the proper
channels these great elements of prosperity to
any people. Debt abroad is the only element
that can, with always a sound currency. enter
into our affairs to cause any continued depresÂ­
sion in the industries and prosperity of our peoÂ­
pile. A general conflict for national existence
k
made necessary, for temporary purposes, the
raising of large sums of money from whatÂ­
ever source attainable. It made necessary, in
the wisdom of Congress, and I do not doubt
their wisdom in the premises, regarding
the necessity of the times, to devise a system of
national currency which proved to be impossiÂ­
ble to keep on a par with the recognized curÂ­
rency of the civilized world. This begot a
spirit of speculation, involving an extravagance
and luxury not required for the happiness or
prosperity of a people, and involving, both diÂ­
rectly and indirectly, foreign indebtedness.
The currency, being of too fluctuating value to
be safe to hold for legitimate transactions reÂ­
quiring money, became a subject of speculation
in itself. These two causes, however, have inÂ­
volved us in a foreign indebtedness, contracted
in good faith by borrower and lender, which
should be paid in coin and according to the
bond agreed upon when the debt was contracted
-gold, or its equivalent. The good faith of
the government cannot be violated towards
creditors at the expense of national disgrace.
Our commerce should be encouraged, AmeriÂ­
can ship-builking and carrying capacity inÂ­
creased, foreign markets sought for the proÂ­
ducts of the soil and manufactories, to the end
that we may be able to pay these debts. Where
a market can be created for the sale of our proÂ­
ducts, either of the soil, the mine or the manÂ­
ufactory. a new means is discovered of utilizing
our idle capital and labor to the advantage of
the whole country.
SPECIE R ESUMITION.
But, in my judgment, the first step towards
aocomplishing this object is to secure a curÂ­
rency good wherever civilization reigns, on
which, if it becomes superabundant with one
people, will find a market with some other; a
currency which has for its basis the labor necÂ­
essary to produce it which will give it value.
Gold and silver are now the recognized mpediÂ­
ums of exchange the civilized world over, and
to this we should return with the least practicÂ­
able delay. In view of the pledges of the
American Congress when our present legal-tenÂ­
der system was adopted and debts contracted,
there should he no delay, certainly no unnecÂ­
essary delay, in fixing by legislation a method
by w.:ichl it will return to specie. To the acÂ­
complishment of this end I invite your attenÂ­
tion. I believe firmly there can be no prosÂ­
perous and permanent revival of business and
industries until a policy is adopted, with legisÂ­
lation to carry it out, looking to a return to
specie basis. It is easy to conceive that the
debtor and speculative classes may think it of
value to make a so-called money abundant unÂ­
til they can throw a portion of their burdens
upon others. But even these, I. believe, would
be disappointed in the result if

With resumption free banking may be inauÂ­

Indeed, I would regard free banking as esÂ­

I have again to call the attention of Congress
te the unsatisfactory condition of the existing
laws with reference to extradition, and the elecÂ­

standing such assertion, and the necessity of fceÂ­
quent application of the principle, legislation
has been had defining what acts or formalities

his citizenship. The importance of such definiÂ­
tion is obvious. The representatives of the
United States in foreign countries are continÂ­
ually called upon to lend their aid and the proÂ­
tection of the United States to persons concernÂ­
ing the good faith, or reality of whose citizenÂ­
ship, there is at least great question. In
some cases the provisions of the treaty furnish
some guide. In others it seems left to the
persons claiming the benefit of citizen
ship while living in a foreign
country, contributing in no manner
by the performance of the duties of citizens of
the United States, and without intention at any
time to return and undertake these duties--who
claim citizenship of the United States simply as
a shield from the performance of the obligaÂ­
tions of citizens elsewhere. The cases of chilÂ­

FRAUDULENT NATURALIZATION.
In this connection I earnestly call the attenÂ­
tion of Congress to the difficilty arising from
fraudulent naturalization. The United States
wisely, freely and liberally offers its citizenship
to all who may come in good faith and reside
within its limits, on their complying with cerÂ­
tain orescribed reasonable formulas and condiÂ­
tions. Among the highest duties of. the
government is that to affbrd firm, efficient
and effectual protection to all citizens, whether
native-born or naturalized. Steps should be
taken that that right, carrying with it such
support from the government, should not be
fraudulently obtained, and should be beÂ­
stowed only' upon full proof of compliance
with the law. There are frequent
instances of illegal and fraudulent naturalizaÂ­
tion and of the unauthorized certificates thus
improperly obtained. In some cases the
fraudulent character of the naturalization has
appeared upon the face of the certificate itself;
in other examinations discloses that the holder
had not complied with the law; and in others
certificates have been obtained where the
persons holding them not only were not enÂ­
titled to be naturalized, but had not even been
within the United States at the time of their
pretended naturalization. Instances of each of
these classes of fraud are discovered at our leÂ­
gations, where the certificates of naturalization
are presented either for the purpose of obtainÂ­
ing passports, or in demanding the protection
of the legation. When fraud was on the face
of such certificates they were taken up by the
representatives of the government
and forwarded to the Department
of State. But even the record of
the court in wlhich fraudulent naturalization


occurred remains, and duplicate certificates are
readily obtainable upon the presentation of these,
for the issue of passports or demanding protecÂ­
tion of the government. The fraud, sometimes
escapes notice, and such certificates are not unÂ­
frequenily used in the transaction of business,
to the deception and injury of innocent parties.
Without placing any additional obstacle in the
way of the obtainment of citizenship by the
worthy and well intentioned foreigner who
comes to cast his lot in good faith with ours, I
earnestly recommend further legislation to punÂ­
ish fraudulent naturalization and to secure the
ready cancelation of the record of every natÂ­
uralization made in fraud.

The efficiency of the navy has been largely

foreign complications which threatened us at

Most of our efficient wooden ships were put in
condition for immediate service, and the repairs
of our ironclad fleet were pushed with the
utmost vigor. The result is that most of these
are effective, and need only to be manned and
set in commission to go at once into service.
Some of the new sloops authorized by

launched, and wait only the completion of their
